results.title: The Killing of Angel Street
results.brief_description: Jessica Simmonds returns home from London and is shocked to find the street she grew up in being torn apart to make way for a high rise development. She sympathises with the plight of the local residents, who are being forced out of their homes by the brutal tactics of the developers. Probing into the background of Angel street development, she unearths a sinister connection between organised crime, the developer, the police and the highest levels of government.

results.title: The Killing of a Chinese bookie
results.creator_credit: Faces Distribution Corporation, Al Ruban and John Cassavetes
results.brief_description: The Killing of a Chinese Bookie presents a portrait of a man who is so self-sufficient that he cannot become personally involved with anyone. Cosmo Vitelli, played by Ben Gazzara, is a nightclub owner who believes in conducting his personal and business affairs with plenty of flair and professionalism. When the mob threatens him he works desperately to save his face and the club.

results.title: The Killing
results.creator_credit: Harris-Kubrick Pictures Corporation, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, James B. Harris and Stanley Kubrick
results.brief_description: A race-track robbery is planned with clockwork precision but Kubrick dispassionately observes how the mechanism is ruined by human fallibility. The intricate flashback structure presents a plot of chess-like moves in a hard boiled, visually stylised underworld richly populated by film noir stereotypes. Based on the novel “Clean Break” by Lionel White. Cast includes Sterling Hayden, Coleen Gray, Vince Edwards and Jay C Flippen.

results.title: The Killer nun = Suor omicidi [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Cinesud, Enzo Gallo and Giulio Berruti
results.brief_description: A former ‘video-nasty’ and one of the few examples of the perversely themed ‘nunsploitation’ genre, which is basically a thinly veiled excuse for some soft core erotica. The usual ingredients for this genre are all present in The Killer nun, that being drug addicted nuns, lesbianism, sadism, murder, necrophilia and lashings of nudity. Anita Ekberg stars as sister Gertrude a sexually repressed, morphine addicted nun who descends into madness when her elderly patients begin to get murdered, making her the prime suspect. Soon enough the unhinged sister is shooting up, having sex with strange men and making inappropriate advances at her fellow sisters. Cast includes Joe Dallesandro, Alida Valli, Lou Castel. Also known as Suor omicidi.

results.title: The Kid stays in the picture
results.creator_credit: Highway Films, Ministry of Propaganda Films, Graydon Carter, Brett Morgan and Nanette Burstein
results.brief_description: Based on the book “The Kid stays in the picture” by Robert Evans comes this documentary about the life of Robert Evans. Good looking actor turned producer and at quite a young age, the head of production at Paramount Studios. This self-made maverick decided that he wanted the power that came with being a producer, witnessed when he, as a young actor, was going to be sacked from a film because he was an unknown. He stayed “in the picture” and as head of the Studio in the late 1960s and early 1970s was responsible for some of the era’s best films such as “The Godfather”, “Rosemary’s Baby”, “Love Story”, “The Odd Couple”, “Harold and Maude” and “Chinatown”. Original interviews and footage from the era combine with a voiceover narration by Robert Evans to give this documentary a lively pace - suited to a man who was once married to Ali MacGraw, had money and power, an unfortunate drug habit and his name muddied by a murder trial. A revealing look into some of the machinations of the Hollywood studio system and the luxurious Hollywood lifestyle.

results.title: The Kid
results.creator_credit: Walt Disney Pictures, Junction Entertainment, Jon Turteltaub, Christina Steinberg and Hunt Lowry
results.brief_description: Bruce Willis plays Russ Duritz, an emotionally detached image consultant who is a winner in business, but a loser in all other areas of his life, especially in regards to his interpersonal skills. Upon meeting Rusty (a ten year old version of himself) Russ starts to reshape himself into a more humane being, partly by revisiting, understanding, and even altering, his past. Cast also includes Spencer Breslin, Emily Mortimer, Lily Tomlin, Chi McBride, Jean Smart.

results.title: The Karate kid. Part 3
results.creator_credit: Columbia Pictures, Jerry Weintraub and John G. Avildsen
results.brief_description: Hoping for a life of peace and tranquility selling bonsais, Daniel and Mr. Miyagi once again find themselves up against the odds. Going against Mr. Miyagi’s wishes, Daniel will defend his title in an All-Valley Championship match arranged by his nemesis, Kreese, whose karate studio folded after his star pupil lost to Daniel. This time Daniel must face ‘the bad boy of karate,’ Mike Barnes. When Mr. Miyagi refuses to train Daniel for the tournament, Daniel inevitably falls into the clutches of Terry (Kreese’s friend, unbeknownst to Daniel), who takes him on as a karate student. Cast includes: Ralph Macchio, Noriyuki Morita, Robyn Lively, Thomas Ian Griffith and Martin Kove.

results.title: The Karate Kid (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Columbia Pictures, Jerry Weintraub and John G. Avildsen
results.brief_description: Daniel, a fatherless teenager, arrives in Los Angeles from the East Coast and faces the difficult task of making new friends. He becomes the object of bullying by a menacing gang of karate students, the Cobras, when he strikes up a relationship with the leader’s ex-girlfriend, Ali. Daniel’s handyman, Miyagi, a master of martial arts, teaches him karate and that fighting is always a last answer to a problem. Daniel learns that karate is a mastery over the self, mind and body, and develops physical skills as well as faith and self confidence.

results.title: The Joy Luck Club
results.creator_credit: Hollywood Pictures, Wayne Wang, Amy Tan, Ronald Bass and Patrick Markey
results.brief_description: Based on Amy Tan’s best-selling novel, “The Joy Luck Club” tells the story of two generations of Chinese women. Four are mothers and wives who emigrated from China to build new lives and families in the United States. The other four are their Chinese-American daughters who are struggling to define their own identities against the expectations of their mothers and the American society where they live. Wayne Wang masterfully interweaves the stories of the eight women which spans from feudal China to modern America, highlighting the similarities and differences between the two generations. “The Joy Luck Club” is a beautiful film to watch, with lavish production values which make the characters’ stories even more compelling.
